If the spirit doesn't know how to make it happen, then it's reasonable to a=
ssume that they are not making it happen.=C2=A0 It really does take a lot o=
f know-how.

And consider this: if the spirit could make a normal tape reco=
rder record by messing with the EMF field near its mic, and it could make a=
 digital recorder record by messing with the EMF field neat its mic, why wo=
uld the spirit even need to delve deeper into the digital world: what worke=
d for the analog tape recorder, still works for the digital recorder, so wh=
y all the mindboggling extra effort for the same result?

Maybe it's that y=
ou don't know how a digital recorder works?=C2=A0 It really doesn't just du=
mp a lot of "digitals" into a nice neat strip, akin to how an analog tape r=
ecorder does to tape.=C2=A0 To record digitally takes many levels of proces=
sing, and a lot of careful digital choreography on the final media.=C2=A0 \=

conv=

Manipulating EMF is one th=
ing.=C2=A0 But directly 
        storing bits on a media is way beyond that=
.=C2=A0 Bits are not stored in 
        a continuous stream.=C2=A0 They are=
 broken into bytes (little packets) 
        that is totally controlled by =
the processor and software.=C2=A0 For 
        Elvis to "encode directly" t=
o the media, he would have to do what that 
        software does to the di=
gital signals coming in from the AtoD converter: 
        he would have to =
group the bits into (for example) 16 little herds each, 
        decide on =
the specific bit interpretation scheme (2's 
        complement?) ,=C2=A0 f=
ind space on the media, update the media's 
        dictionary of where the=
re is free space and where there isn't, link the 
        herds together wi=
th some sort of linked pointer, skip around the areas 
        marked 'bad'=
 on the media, update things like date/time modified and 
        size, res=
pect any kind of ownership permissions on the media, and so 
        on.

I=
t is much more credible for the signal to be manipulated 
        near the =
AtoD converter (where EMF changes would have the most 
        straighforwa=
rd result) than in the digital media itself.

                  analog element (the Analog t=
o Digital converter) which takes 
                  the sound pressure wave=
s, as represented by some analog 
                  electronic detection el=
ement, and converts that into 
                  digital.=C2=A0 That way, l=
ong departed uncle Ebenezer does not 
                  need to do anything=
 digital.=C2=A0 Under this scenario, if 
                  sound is not bei=
ng heard in the room, but is being induced 
                  into the circ=
uitry, then it would be round about that AtoD 
                  converter =
(assuming it isn't other just plain old noise in the 
                  dig=
ital elements).=C2=A0 

Someone with more electronic 
                  kno=
w-how than me might be able to better pinpoint the area in

                 =
 recorder.

      <td valign=3D"top"><br>Manipulating EMF is one thing.&nbs=
p; But directly 
        storing bits on a media is way beyond that.  =
Bits are not stored in 
        a continuous stream.  They are broken =
into bytes (little packets) 
        that is totally controlled by the proc=
essor and software.  For 
        Elvis to "encode directly" to the me=
dia, he would have to do what that 
        software does to the digital si=
gnals coming in from the AtoD converter: 
        he would have to group th=
e bits into (for example) 16 little herds each, 
        decide on the spec=
ific bit interpretation scheme (2's 
        complement?) ,  find spac=
e on the media, update the media's 
        dictionary of where there is fr=
ee space and where there isn't, link the

rts that into 
                  digital.  That way, long departed unc=
le Ebenezer does not
